ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: I learned a lot about Holocaust narrative in academic and intellectual circles, along with a more comprehensive look at the public's use and perception of the Holocaust in historical and contemporary discussions.
I come away from this course having grown immensely as a thinker. Professor Stern and Lital challenged us to become better readers, writers, thinkers, and communicators, and I feel so lucky for that.
How to analyze the commemoration and politicization of the Holocaust through a critical lens.

In this course I gained an understanding of how the Holocaust is understood in a historical framework. This course wasn't about understanding the history of the Holocaust, rather, it was about understanding how the history of the Holocaust is used to fuel contemporary debates, or other themes.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments:
Strengths - great readings, great discussions anchored by an amazing professor and TF who brought both their wealths of knowledge and intellectual minds to these discussions; teaching new material but made it digestible
Weaknesses - having the class once a week made it feel too spaced out and then condensed
I have no improvements. An excellent, well-organized, engaging class through and through.
Individual presentations are a strength and zoom classes were a weakness

Strengths: amazing discussions, knowledgeable professor, fun readings
Weaknesses: Professor tended to talk a lot in the discussions, so it would have been great to hear more students talk

The strengths of this course will come from the students who participate in it. Prof. Stern allows ample space for student discussion, but makes clear that this course is not one where someone can simply sit and listen to the conversation. In addition, the TA, Lital, was amazing. She met with me whenever I needed to discuss the writing prompts, and offered thorough and clear feedback.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: I would definitely recommend this course. You learn a lot about things that are not only interesting and less talked about, such as the underlying Holocaust narrative and how it crops up in different areas of society, but also have lessons that are really relevant to today

Without a doubt! The course was not only timing and engaging, but it encouraged us to re-evaluate many of the ideas regarding Judaism, the Holocaust, antisemitism, and Israel that I had long taken for granted.
Absolutely! This is an amazing and enriching course.

I would recommend this course to any student interested in understanding the idea of how history can be "used," because it allows another viewpoint into the discipline. Having some background in Holocaust/modern European history would also be a plus.
